trans-unit.source: testmdarticle
trans-unit.target: testmdarticle

trans-unit.source: Manage Windows with PowerShell Direct
trans-unit.target: Manage Windows with PowerShell Direct

trans-unit.source: You can use PowerShell Direct to remotely manage a Windows 10 or Windows Server Technical Preview virtual machine from a Windows 10 or Windows Server Technical Preview Hyper-V host.
trans-unit.target: You can use PowerShell Direct to remotely manage a Windows 10 or Windows Server Technical Preview virtual machine from a Windows 10 or Windows Server Technical Preview Hyper-V host.

trans-unit.source: PowerShell Direct allows PowerShell management inside a virtual machine regardless of the network configuration or remote management settings on either the Hyper-V host or the virtual machine.
trans-unit.target: PowerShell Direct allows PowerShell management inside a virtual machine regardless of the network configuration or remote management settings on either the Hyper-V host or the virtual machine.

trans-unit.source: This makes it easier for Hyper-V Administrators to automate and script virtual machine management and configuration.
trans-unit.target: This makes it easier for Hyper-V Administrators to automate and script virtual machine management and configuration.

trans-unit.source: There are two ways to run PowerShell Direct:
trans-unit.target: There are two ways to run PowerShell Direct:

trans-unit.source: Create and exit a PowerShell Direct session using PSSession cmdlets
trans-unit.target: Create and exit a PowerShell Direct session using PSSession cmdlets

trans-unit.source: Run script or command with the Invoke-Command cmdlet
trans-unit.target: Run script or command with the Invoke-Command cmdlet

trans-unit.source: If you're managing older virtual machines, use Virtual Machine Connection (VMConnect) or
trans-unit.target: If you're managing older virtual machines, use Virtual Machine Connection (VMConnect) or

trans-unit.source: configure a virtual network for the virtual machine
trans-unit.target: configure a virtual network for the virtual machine

trans-unit.source: Create and exit a PowerShell Direct session using PSSession cmdlets
trans-unit.target: Create and exit a PowerShell Direct session using PSSession cmdlets

trans-unit.source: On the Hyper-V host, open Windows PowerShell as Administrator.
trans-unit.target: On the Hyper-V host, open Windows PowerShell as Administrator.

trans-unit.source: Run the one of the following commands to create a session by using the virtual machine name or GUID: ``` PowerShell Enter-PSSession -VMName VMName Enter-PSSession -VMGUID VMGUID
trans-unit.target: Run the one of the following commands to create a session by using the virtual machine name or GUID: ``` PowerShell Enter-PSSession -VMName VMName Enter-PSSession -VMGUID VMGUID

trans-unit.source: Note: If you're session won't connect, make sure you're using credentials for the virtual machine you're connecting to -- not the Hyper-V host.
trans-unit.target: Note: If you're session won't connect, make sure you're using credentials for the virtual machine you're connecting to -- not the Hyper-V host.

trans-unit.source: To learn more about these cmdlets, see
trans-unit.target: To learn more about these cmdlets, see

trans-unit.source: Enter-PSSession
trans-unit.target: Enter-PSSession

trans-unit.source: and
trans-unit.target: and

trans-unit.source: Exit-PSSession
trans-unit.target: Exit-PSSession

trans-unit.source: Run script or command with Invoke-Command cmdlet
trans-unit.target: Run script or command with Invoke-Command cmdlet

trans-unit.source: You can use the
trans-unit.target: You can use the

trans-unit.source: Invoke-Command
trans-unit.target: Invoke-Command

trans-unit.source: cmdlet to run a pre-determined set of commands on the virtual machine.
trans-unit.target: cmdlet to run a pre-determined set of commands on the virtual machine.

trans-unit.source: Here is an example of how you can use the Invoke-Command cmdlet where PSTest is the virtual machine name and the script to run (foo.ps1) is in the script folder on the C:/ drive:
trans-unit.target: Here is an example of how you can use the Invoke-Command cmdlet where PSTest is the virtual machine name and the script to run (foo.ps1) is in the script folder on the C:/ drive:

trans-unit.source: ``` PowerShell Invoke-Command -VMName PSTest -FilePath C:\script\foo.ps1
trans-unit.target: ``` PowerShell Invoke-Command -VMName PSTest -FilePath C:\script\foo.ps1

trans-unit.source: What's required to use PowerShell Direct?
trans-unit.target: What's required to use PowerShell Direct?

trans-unit.source: To create a PowerShell Direct session on a virtual machine,
trans-unit.target: To create a PowerShell Direct session on a virtual machine,

trans-unit.source: The virtual machine must be running locally on the host and booted.
trans-unit.target: The virtual machine must be running locally on the host and booted.

trans-unit.source: You must be logged into the host computer as a Hyper-V administrator.
trans-unit.target: You must be logged into the host computer as a Hyper-V administrator.

trans-unit.source: You must supply valid user credentials for the virtual machine.
trans-unit.target: You must supply valid user credentials for the virtual machine.

trans-unit.source: The host operating system must run Windows 10, Windows Server Technical Preview, or a higher version.
trans-unit.target: The host operating system must run Windows 10, Windows Server Technical Preview, or a higher version.

trans-unit.source: The virtual machine must run Windows 10, Windows Server Technical Preview, or a higher version.
trans-unit.target: The virtual machine must run Windows 10, Windows Server Technical Preview, or a higher version.

trans-unit.source: You can use the
trans-unit.target: You can use the

trans-unit.source: Get-VM
trans-unit.target: Get-VM

trans-unit.source: cmdlet to check that the credentials you're using have the Hyper-V administrator role and to see which VMs are running locally on the host and booted.
trans-unit.target: cmdlet to check that the credentials you're using have the Hyper-V administrator role and to see which VMs are running locally on the host and booted.

trans-unit.source: What can you do with PowerShell Direct?
trans-unit.target: What can you do with PowerShell Direct?

trans-unit.source: See
trans-unit.target: See

trans-unit.source: PowerShell Direct snippets
trans-unit.target: PowerShell Direct snippets

trans-unit.source: for numerous examples of how to use PowerShell Direct in your environment as well as tips and tricks for writing Hyper-V scripts with PowerShell.
trans-unit.target: for numerous examples of how to use PowerShell Direct in your environment as well as tips and tricks for writing Hyper-V scripts with PowerShell.
